none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, March 22, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, March 22, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 11 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: J. T. Hand writes to Louis L. McInnis from Brenham, Texas, expressing condolences regarding the death of their mutual friend Moore, who died following a fifth attack of illness. Hand discusses his concern about the financial state of Moore's affairs and reflects on Moore's character, noting he had held McInnis in high regard. The letter also addresses the anticipated organization of a Texas university, speculating on faculty selection procedures and expressing Hand's own interest in a position, while critiquing the traditional Texas practice of requiring applicants to seek academic posts through political endorsements rather than merit-based recruitment.

body.value:
[Header]

Brenham Mar 22 - 1882.

My Dear Professor:

Your good letter
to "hand" - read & reread with pleasure.
You have doubtless seen from the
News that our friend Moore is
gone - It was an event not
unexpected to me - I feel real
sad over it - The fifth attack
carried him off - I spent an
hour with him on Friday eve -
in the office of Exchange Hotel.
Told me he was not feeling as
well as he had been feeling for
some days - but said he was
going to Austin Next day on
Noon train & return Sunday night
About 3 oclock that night (Friday)
his hard breathing awoke a gentle-
man in the adjoining room -
Major Wilson was called & when
he reached his room he was speechless
& unconscious - The tide of life was
rapidly ebbing away - He never
rallied & died at 10-30 Sunday P. M.

**Here's how I approached this transcription, as a seasoned professional:** 1. **Understanding the Assignment:** First, I digested the instructions. I knew my role was a skilled transcriptionist. The task was clear: meticulously convert the handwritten text into a digital format. I needed to maintain accuracy (spelling, punctuation), handle ambiguous handwriting using placeholders like "[?]" or "[illegible]", and preserve the original layout (paragraphs, margins) as much as possible, as well as label structural elements like `[Header]`. The goal was a clean transcription, nothing more. 2. **Analyzing the Visual Clues:** I examined the image itself. I noted it was a handwritten letter, likely with purple ink on lined paper, and there was a fold. There was a date in the top right, a salutation in the top left, and then a narrative concerning the death of someone named Moore. This information primed me for the content. 3. **Line-by-Line Transcription with Intense Scrutiny:** * I began by dissecting the text, line by line. I started with the header. The guidelines said "label structural elements". I decided to use `[Header]` to indicate it was a header. * The date was "Brenham Mar 22 - 1882." * Salutation: "My Dear Professor:" * Body: * Line 1: I noticed the insertion of "Your" above "good letter". I would include that in the text. * I meticulously analyzed each word, focusing on legibility and letter shapes. This led to some challenges with the letter "f". * I got stuck on line 6: "unexpected to me - I feel ...". The word was unclear. It looked like "feel full" or "feel real." I engaged in thorough analysis and eventually concluded it read "I feel **real** sad." (but it could have been "feel full"). * Then on line 23 I had to determine if the death was "Sunday P.M." or "Sunday A.M.". The loop at the end of the line was the key indicator. Based on the timing given in the other lines, the death took place on Sunday P.M. * The word "Exchange" in line 10 had me wondering. I looked and decided that the first letter was a messy "E". * I had to make sure to transcribe all proper names and the line breaks (using `
`). 4. **Refinement and Cross-Checking:** * I double-checked all names and locations. I carefully looked at each ambiguous letter or character. I made sure that the line breaks were correct. * I examined the word "real" again to be extra careful. The letter shapes led me to this word choice. I did a similar, detailed check for "P.M." 5. **Final Polish and HTML Formatting:** * I reviewed the entire transcription against the image one last time to confirm accuracy. * I incorporated HTML tags, specifically `

` for paragraphs and `
` for line breaks. I decided to visually align the header through text, using the given structure: `[Header]` and `

`. I was now confident in the completed transcription, ready for use!

[1882, March 22]

He was expecting to be married
in a short time - but alas! how
utterly helpless is man!
I regret to tell you that he died
under a financial cloud -
how dense I can not tell.
He had many noble traits of character
He thought much of you & often spoke of
you - I am loser by his death -
I shall always love to call up his
many genial traits of character.

Your impression is that the University
Regents will elect a faculty at an
early day & that the University will
be organized next fall.
How is the organization of the
University possible next fall?
Do you think the University will
be organized in advance of the
erection of Buildings? . I think
the Gov, would like to make it
a Monument of his administration
if possible - yet I can't see
how he is to surmount the
difficulty of adequate buildings -

**Thought Process: Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's how I'm approaching this transcription task. First, I need to understand the instructions. I'm a transcriptionist, and my job is to accurately reproduce the text from the image, following the specified guidelines. The goal is to provide a transcription, *only*. No extra commentary allowed. I'm analyzing the provided constraints. I need to make sure I am only using a, b, br, i, img, p, small, span, sub, sup HTML tags. I have to read the text from top to bottom, which is standard. Any uncertainty will be marked with a question mark. Illegible sections should be marked as [illegible]. The layout, including paragraphs and any marginalia, must be preserved. And, of course, I need to use Markdown for any tables. Okay, got it. Now, I'm examining the image itself. I can see it's a handwritten letter on lined paper. The writing is in purple ink and appears to be cursive. It's generally legible, although it seems a bit hurried, and it looks like a late 19th-century hand. There's a pencil notation in the top right corner and creases indicating it was folded. I'll start transcribing line by line, paying attention to every detail. First, the pencil notation: "[1882, March 22]". That seems straightforward. Next, I'll transcribe the letter. Here's what I'm seeing: * "He was expecting to be married" * "in a short time - but alas! how" * "utterly helpless is man!" * "I regret to tell you that he died" * "under a financial cloud -" * "how dense I can not tell." * "He had many noble traits of character" * "He thought much of you & often spoke of" * "you - I am loser by his death -" * "I shall always love to call up his" * "many genial traits of character." * "Your impression is that the University" * "Regents will elect a faculty at an" * "early day & that the University will" * "be organized next fall." * "How is the organization of the" * "University possible next fall?" * "Do you think the University will" * "be organized in advance of the" * "erection of Buildings? . I think" * "the Gov, would like to make it" * "a Monument of his administration" * "if possible - yet I can't see" * "how he is to surmount the" * "difficulty of adequate buildings -" Now, I'm checking for HTML compliance. Since the instructions say to "Maintain paragraph structures" and "Preserve... line breaks", I'll use `

` tags for paragraphs and `
` tags for the visual line breaks *within* those paragraphs. Looking at the text, the pencil date stands alone. The remaining text looks like two paragraphs. I need to look for indentations to be sure. It looks like it is: * Line 1: "He was..." - This starts an indented block. * Line 12: "Your impression..." - This starts an indented block. So, two paragraphs, each with multiple lines. I'm also double-checking individual words, like "elect", "erection", and "surmount", making sure I'm interpreting them correctly. I will also check all punctuation for accuracy and context (e.g., dashes, exclamation points, commas). Now for the final HTML construction. I'll put the date in its own paragraph block: `

[1882, March 22]

`. I considered a `span` or something but it is by itself, so a paragraph is fine. For the first paragraph: `He was expecting to be married
in a short time - but alas! how
utterly helpless is man!
I regret to tell you that he died
under a financial cloud -
how dense I can not tell.
He had many noble traits of character
He thought much of you & often spoke of
you - I am loser by his death -
I shall always love to call up his
many genial traits of character.` For the second paragraph: `Your impression is that the University
Regents will elect a faculty at an
early day & that the University will
be organized next fall.
How is the

[1882, March 22]

What do you think will be the policy
of the Regents? The selection of
a member of your faculty
I should say lies between you &
Dinwiddie – This is my impression –
I have no means of knowing
what will be the method of the
Regents in electing a faculty –
Heretofore in Texas, if a man
wants a place in village Academy
or State College he must ask
for it & support his application
with numerous "endorsations" –
In the case of State Institutions
especially, I think, scholarly men –
Capable men – Successful men –
laborious men should be sought &
obtained – but I apprehend the
Regents will not depart
from the custom which has
obtained heretofore –
If the University can be eliminated
wholly from politics, I would be
glad to have the chair of Ancient
Languages or Moral Philosophy –

**Transcription Process: A Deep Dive**

Okay, here's how I approached this transcription task. First, I locked into the requirements: I'm a professional transcriber, my mission is to accurately convert this handwritten text into a digital format, and I have strict guidelines. No commentary, preserve the original spelling and punctuation, and adhere to specific HTML tags for formatting. I'm starting with a single-page image – purple ink on lined paper, dated March 22, 1882, in pencil at the top right, and it's cursive. It's late 19th-century cursive, with frequent dashes.

I began by scanning the text. I noted the date first: *[1882, March 22]*.  Since the prompt emphasizes "layout", I'll put it as a paragraph at the top. Then, line by line, I started the painstaking work.

"What do you think will be the policy," clear enough. "of the Regents? The selection of," – Regents is capitalized, and it's a question, so the question mark stays. "a member of your faculty." "I should say lies between you &" – here's where it got interesting. "say" was a bit blurred, looked like "soy" or "try" at first, but with a closer look, the context of "lies between" made "say" the only logical choice. I did a double-take – the 's' is a bit unusual, and the tail of the 'y' can look like it loops back. The handwriting style makes it tricky, but I'm confident in "say." And that ampersand – looks like a "plus" or "crossed t" in the style of writing, but it's an ampersand.

Then came "Dinwiddie – This is my impression –". "Dinwiddie" I carefully considered: the letters were loose cursive, but given the time period, Texas University connection, and the context, I'm pretty sure it's "Dinwiddie". "I have no means of knowing" – I made sure the "means" was clear; it’s m-e-a-n-s, not "reasons". "what will be the method of the Regents in electing a faculty –".  "Heretofore in Texas, if a man". Capital "H" and capital "T". "wants a place in village Academy", with "Academy" capitalized. "or State College he must *ask*." Here's a key point. Underlined! I know the prompt limits the HTML to *i*, *b*, *br*, but I will represent the underlining with `<i>` – for emphasis.

"for it & support his application with numerous "endorsations" –" – "endorsations" is in quotes; keeping that. "In the case of State Institutions, especially, I think, scholarly men –" I checked the spelling; "especially". "Capable men – Successful men – laborious men should be sought & obtained –". "laborious" I triple checked, just to be sure. "but I apprehend the Regents will not depart from the custom which has obtained heretofore –". The rest was fairly straightforward: "If the University can be eliminated wholly from politics, I would be glad to have the chair of Ancient Languages or Moral Philosophy –"

I reviewed it all again, line by line, checking for any missed nuances. I double-checked "Dinwiddie" – and, while the cursive is a bit loose, that's what it is, and what makes sense historically and contextually. The dashes I interpreted as dashes. I then constructed the output using the required HTML tags, making sure everything was in the correct order, that I’d kept the line breaks. I re-checked spelling, making sure it aligned with the text and then did a final review. I re-read the final draft, verifying each letter. Done.

[1882, March 22]

You see that the irrepressible Hogg
is now associated with Hollingsworth
on Journal of Education - He'll "turn up"
somewhere or somehow -
I wish I could see you - I want
to talk over matters which I can
not write - I see from the
paper that Edrington - the
Howells Capt Beall all leave
Bryan - That is a hard lick
on Bryan - Our Monthly examination
commences to-morrow & I have
some papers to prepare to-night
Let me hear from you soon -

Your Friend
Hana

**Analysis and Transcription of a Handwritten Document**

Okay, here we go. I've got a handwritten document here, dated March 22, 1882, written in purple ink. Looks like a personal letter of some kind, signed "Hana" (or maybe "Hand" - let's keep an eye on that). My task is to transcribe this, line by line, being as accurate as possible.

First, the writing itself: Cursive, a little hurried, but generally legible. I see the name Hogg, along with Hollingsworth, mentioned in the context of the *Journal of Education*. This is interesting. This is likely about Texas, given who these people are. The author references some "Edrington," the "Howells," and "Capt. Beall," who are all leaving Bryan. There is reference to a monthly examination and papers for the author to prepare, which suggests a teaching context, and potentially some inside information regarding a community in decline. I must investigate these names and links later.

Now, line-by-line transcription. I will go through this carefully. I'm focusing on the characters first, and then on the words. Here's what I've got:

*   **Line 1:** "You see that the irrepressible Hogg" - "Hogg" looks good.
*   **Line 2:** "is now associated with Hollingsworth" - A bit scribbly, but "associated" fits. The name "Hollingsworth" looks correct.
*   **Line 3:** "on Journal of Education - He'll "turn up"" - "Journal of Education" is clear. Quotes around "turn up."
*   **Line 4:** "somewhere or somehow -" - Straightforward.
*   **Line 5:** "I wish I could see you - I want" - Clear.
*   **Line 6:** "to talk over matters which I can" - No issues.
*   **Line 7:** "not write - I see from the" - Straightforward.
*   **Line 8:** "paper that Edrington - the" - "Edrington" is clear.
*   **Line 9:** "Howells Capt Beall all leave" - "Capt Beall" may actually be "Copt" but context implies "Capt" (Captain). I'll double check.
*   **Line 10:** "Bryan - That is a hard lick" - "hard lick" makes sense idiomatically. Bryan is clear.
*   **Line 11:** "on Bryan - Our Monthly examination" - "Monthly" is capitalized. "examination" ends with the typical -tion shorthand.
*   **Line 12:** "commences to-morrow & I have" - Ampersand used.
*   **Line 13:** "some papers to prepare to-night" - "some" looks a little odd, but is correct.
*   **Line 14:** "Let me hear from you soon -" - Clear.
*   **Line 15:** "Your Friend" - "Hana" - The signature might be "Hand", but let's stick with what the shapes suggest until I have a very good reason to think otherwise. "Hana" it is. It looks like an 'a' without the top closed.

Now, a couple of specific points to re-evaluate:

*   The "Capt" in line 9. It *could* be "Copt," but "Capt" (Captain) is much more likely given the time period and context. Let's see if this lines up with people in Bryan, Texas, in 1882. *Maybe it is an abbreviation and not a word?* But what is an abbreviated 'Copt' or 'Capt'? A title maybe? Lieutenant?
*   Signature. It looks like "Hana". However, it could be a stylized "Hand." There's no vertical stroke on the last letter. Let's look up the people "Hogg" "Hollingsworth" "Journal of Education". Hogg and Hollingsworth were in the Texas Journal.

**Let's check the date** \[1882, March 22]. Pencil.

**Structure is key:** The order of the transcription reflects top-to-bottom reading. It is one paragraph, except the signature and the date.

So, after a final check, here is my final transcription:

**[1882, March 22]**

You see that the irrepressible Hogg
is now associated with Hollingsworth
on Journal of Education - He'll "turn up"
somewhere or somehow -
I wish I could see you - I want
to talk over matters which I can
not
